reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central element: the post leans on CES-style “max speed/late bottleneck for −0.2<ρ<0” reasoning while also arguing a paradigm-switching/“strongest link” picture, and tension here could undermine the robustness of the quantitative takeaway. However, the critique only partially refutes the position: pointing out aggregation-model mismatch mainly shows the CES-derived ceilings/plateau dynamics may not carry over when the system can switch methods, not that compute bottlenecks will in fact bite earlier or that an SIE is impossible. It’s partly correct that CES (single smooth production function) and a max-over-routes model imply different dynamics, but it overstates incompatibility because the author explicitly presents the “strongest link” framing as an alternative and could consistently interpret CES as applying within a route and then take a max across routes. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: CES smooth substitution conflicts with discrete route-switching dynamics
